data.value: Large supermarkets, Commercial centre, Boutiques, Bars, Restaurants

data.name: LaRodalLocationInfoDetail
data.value: Dans le coin sud-est de la province de Séville, La Roda de Andalucía est un village de 4300 habitants. Entouré d'oliviers, il abrite l'église baroque du XVIIe siècle de Santa Ana.

data.name: LaRodalLocationInfoDetail1
data.value: The numerous festivities in La Roda include a pilgrimage in honour of San Pancracio on the second Sunday in May, the festival of María Auxiliadora on the 24th of May, the fiesta of San Pedro on the last weekend of June and fiesta in honour of the Virgen del Carmen on the 16th of July.

data.name: LaRodalLocationInfoDetail2
data.value: Also celebrated enthusiastically on the first weekend of August is the Verbena del Emigrante.

data.name: LaRodalLocationInfoDetail3
data.value: La Roda is situated on the A92 motorway 18km from Estepa on the border with the province of Córdoba. There is a train station just outside the town and trains can be taken from here to various parts of Andalucía.

data.name: MarchenaLocationInfoDetail
data.value: Soixante kilomètres au sud de Séville, dans les ondulantes céréales et oliviers de La Campiña de la vallée du Guadalquivir se trouve Marchena. Cette jolie ville joliment aspergée de monuments bien conservés était à son apogée présidée par les ducs d'Arcos, qui bâtissaient l'élégante colonnade carré, le Plaza Ducal, en face de ce qui utilisé à être la dukes' majestueuse manoir, qui a été tristement démoli au début du 20e siècle.

data.name: MarchenaLocationInfoDetail1
data.value: Marchena is worth a visit for its collection of paintings by one of Spain's finest 17th-century artists, Francisco de Zubarán from Extremadura, along with other religious art.

data.name: MarchenaLocationInfoDetail2
data.value: The town has a long history, whose settlers left their mark most notably with the town walls, first constructed by the Romans, revamped by the Moors and largely rebuilt by the Christians under Ferdinand III, who captured the town in 1240. Today, the restored Torre de Oro is the most impressive tower along this wall, while the Puerta de Sevilla, also known as the Arco de la Rosa, is the best gate.

data.name: MarchenaLocationInfoDetail3
data.value: In the mid-14th century the town became a seigneury of Ponce de León and in the next century, the dukes of Arcos.

data.name: MarchenaLocationInfoDetail4
data.value: Don't miss the Mudéjar parish church of San Juan Bautista, which houses the Museo Zubarán in its sacristy, with nine magnificent religious paintings by the renowned artist, of which the best is undoubtedly the canvas of La Inmaculada. Also part of the museum is a collection of intricately worked silver and gold liturgical objects, many dating from the 15th and 16th centuries. The museum is open on Saturday and Sunday from 11am to 2pm. In the church are two 17th-century sculptures by Alonso Cano and Pedro de Mena. The church itself is built in the Gothic-Mudéjar style and dates from the 14th century.

data.name: MarchenaLocationInfoDetail5
data.value: Built on the former site of a mosque, the Gothic-Mudéjar church of Santa María de la Mota has a fine Renaissance tower and belfry.

data.name: MarchenaLocationInfoDetail6
data.value: From Marchena you can walk, cycle or ride on horseback along the Vía Verde of the Countryside, a greenway that follows the course of an old railway line for 91km to Valchillón just outside Cordoba.

data.name: MarinaledaLocationDetail
data.value: A small village located in flat surroundings of wheat fields, Marinaleda would be relatively unknown were it not for its political associations.

data.name: MarinaledaLocationDetail1
data.value: Marinaleda is an administrative area of Seville, consisting of two villages, Marinaleda (population around 2,000) and Matarredonda (population around 600) which are gradually becoming joined by development between the two. It is more or less central to the triangle formed by Malaga, Seville and Granada. It is close to Ecija, Estepa, Osuna, Herrera and Punters Genil. A little over an hour from the coast. It is served by a bus service to Seville, summer day trips to the coast and excellent train service to Malaga, Seville etc. from Herrera station just a short taxi ride away. The village is mostly ﬂat and easy to get around and park.

data.name: MarinaledaLocationDetail2
data.value: Marinaleda boasts impressive facilities. There is a pool complex with bar, two football pitches, two municipal parks, one has an amphitheater for events, a gymnasium, sports pavilion, tennis courts, a Casa de Cultura with a computer suite. There is free Wi-Fi for residents and a pool pass costs just €5 for the summer. Local taxes are among the lowest in Spain. There are free (and gentle) Spanish language and culture classes at the Adult Educational Centre. There’s a wide variety of bars and restaurants from the Union bar (Sindicato) to a wine and cocktails bar (Oﬁcina). There are plenty of small supermarkets and other shops and a weekly market on Wednesdays. Recently opened are a Cash and Carry and a Moorish “Tetaría” (tea and infusions bar). There are two venues that regularly hold a variety of live music concerts, most are free.

data.name: MarinaledaLocationDetail3
data.value: The central avenue (Avenida de Libertad) has gardens and a fountain which is lit up of a night. There’s a local bakery, greengrocers, a ﬁshmongers, two barbers and a hairdresser.! The town is run by the Mayor, Juan Manuel Sanchez Gordillo, who is very accessible and accommodating to foreign residents. Until 2013, he was very active politically and, in the 80’s and 90’s secured a Cooperative Farm for the village about 12 kms away. In 2012 , a new factory was completed for processing the food products. Most local farmers use a cooperative "1 olive oil plant in the village and there are two local food processing businesses. There are two banks with cash machines.

data.name: MoronLocationInfoDetail
data.value: La ville blanchie à la chaux de Moron de la Frontera s'élève au-dessus de la plaine de patchwork roulant de La Campiña comme un mirage. C'était autrefois un centre important d'un taifa (état) mauresque et nommé d'après la place des Maures. Il est dominé par son château médiéval ruiné, avec plusieurs églises impressionnantes parsemées autour de ses jolies rues étroites.

data.name: MoronLocationInfoDetail1
data.value: On the border of Cadiz and Seville provinces, Moron de la Frontera was in an important defensive position and its castle was one of the most important in the area. Later it became home to the nobility, when the duchy of Osuna made it a residence and adorned it with marble fittings and artesanado coffered ceilings. The castle was almost destroyed by the French in 1812.

data.name: MoronLocationInfoDetail2
data.value: Visit the nearby Paseo del Gallo, a small square with great views over the town.

data.name: MoronLocationInfoDetail3
data.value: Declared a site of cultural interest, the Iglesia de San Miguel has a ornate Baroque portal designed by Diego Antonio Díaz and a 17th-century bell tower, built on the site of a Moorish minaret, modeled along the lines of Seville cathedral's Giralda. San Ignacio church dates from the early 18th century and has an impressive Baroque portal, carved from sandstone.

data.name: MoronLocationInfoDetail4
data.value: Inside is a collection of large oil religious paintings by the Flemish painter Peter van Lint.

data.name: MoronLocationInfoDetail5
data.value: Visit the town in July when its annual flamenco festival is in full swing, one of the best known of its kind and known as Gazpacho Andaluz. Established in 1963, it features flamenco baile (dance) and cante (song) and serves the customary gazpacho, the typical Andalucian chilled soup.

data.name: OsunaLocationInfoDetail
data.value: Les origines de la ville s'étirer remontent à l'an 1000 av. comme on peut le constater par le grand nombre restes de chaque période historique. Osuna a obtenu son nom des Turdetans, un hommage ibérique lequel l'appelait Urso; Plusieurs objets restent de ceci période, comme le «Taureau d'Osuna» et «Relief d'Osuna» (ces derniers montrant une Influence romaine).

data.name: OsunaLocationInfoDetail1
data.value: The origins of the town stretch back to the year 1000 BC, as can be seen by the great number of remains from each historical period. Osuna got its name from the Turdetans, an Iberian tribute which called it Urso; several objects remain from this period, such as the "Bull of Osuna" et l' "Relief's of Osuna" (these latter showing a Roman Influence).

data.name: OsunaLocationInfoDetail2
data.value: When Pompey made his last unsuccessful stand against Caesar in Osuna, the city fell into his rival's hands, and Caesar gave it the status of a colony (Colonia Genetiva Iulia), the importance of which is suggested by the laws found in the "Osuna Bronzes".

data.name: OsunaLocationInfoDetail3
data.value: We know very little about the Visigothic period, and the subsequent Moorish rule. All that remains of the period of the almohad rule are a few sections of the ramparts and a tower, the Torre del Agua.

data.name: OsunaLocationInfoDetail4
data.value: King Ferdinand III (the Saint) conquered the town in 1239. In 1264, King Alfonso X granted Osuna to the Order of Calatrava (or which it was a major encomienda or concession).

data.name: OsunaLocationInfoDetail5
data.value: In 1460, while the Master of the Order was Pedro Giron, the town was traded fro Fuenteovejuna and Belmez, as a result of which it became the seat of the Counts of Ureña. In 1562 the 5th Count of Ureña was made 1st Duke of Osuna, and from then on Osuna became the Andalucian capital of the domains of the Tellez Giron family, who were the founders of the Collegiate Church and the University in the 16th century.

data.name: OsunaLocationInfoDetail6
data.value: The Giron family, with their many religious foundations, did much to make the urban landscape of Osuna what it is today, with its mixture of convents and churches, lordly palaces and manors, overlooked by the cliff on which stands the Collegiate Church, the University and the remains of the ducal palace.

data.name: AlamedaLocationDetail
data.value: Ce village de 5.500 habitant se trouve au nord-ouest d'Alameda est probablement plus célèbre pour sa cadavérique célébrité El Tempranillo, le légendaire 19th siècle bandit né à Jauja et enterré dans Iglesía de l'Alameda de la Purísima Concepción église. Le soi-disant Principe de la Sierra, prince des montagnes, est le plus coloré de Andalucía's beaucoup de héros bandit

data.name: AlamedaLocationDetail1
data.value: Alameda a été réglé comme une ville par les Phéniciens, mais il ya des preuves archéologiques d'habitation datant du paléolithique et néolithique, probablement 2-2,500 BCE. Des vestiges de ces colonies peuvent être vus à l' Necrópolis Calcolítica juste à l'extérieur de la ville, un système de plus de vingt fosses interconnectés ou ossuaires, dont certains d'un mètre de large.

data.name: AlamedaLocationDetail2
data.value: Alameda a également été un règlement important à l'époque romaine, avec les restes d'une villa et des thermes romains et une richesse d'artefacts découverts suggérant un commerce important et une base militaire sur le site au cours du premier siècle avant JC. Le reste des bains sont maintenus dans une enceinte de 3000 mètres carrés dans la Calle Enmedio, et ont été datées entre le premier et le troisième siècles AC. Le site est maintenant un monument national protégé.

data.name: AlamedaLocationDetail3
data.value: Comme une grande partie de la région, il a été envahie par les envahisseurs wisigoths et plus tard par les colons maures dans le huitième siècle. Les reconquistadores catholiques ont pris la ville en 1240, relativement tôt dans la Reconquête, et quand le nouvel ordre espagnol a été établie la ville, puis un petit hameau, a été placé sous le contrôle de l' Marqués d'Alameda, au nord-ouest de la ville. La région elle-même était sous la domination de l'Ordre de Santiago - les chevaliers de Saint-James - jusqu'en 1559, moment où Alameda avait à peine trente habitants.

data.name: AlamedaLocationDetail4
data.value: La ville s'est développée au cours du 17ème siècle, grâce à sa spécialisation dans l'alfa, le bois et la menuiserie (une version de l'origine de son nom provient d'un bosquet de peupliers), et un afflux de colons venus Alameda lui-même.

data.name: AlamedaLocationDetail5
data.value: En 1883 Alameda a été incorporé dans la province nouvellement créé de Málaga, sous le contrôle de Archidona. Ce fut une décision impopulaire et source de confusion dans un village qui était encore sous les ordres de l'évêque à la fois d'Alameda et l'archevêque de Séville. La ville ne fut placé sous les ordres de l'archevêque Alaga aussi tard que 1959.

data.name: AlamedaLocationDetail6
data.value: Le baroque Iglesía de la Purísima Concepción a été construit en 1696, le clocher de l'église étant un ajout plus tard, avec le retable rococo remarquable à la tête de la nef. L'église a été effectivement élargi latéralement en 1779 avec deux nouvelles nefs, soutenues par huit piliers massifs, pour accueillir en plein essor nouvelle population de la ville. Le tombeau d'El Tempranillo peut être vu dans le patio intérieur de l'église.

data.name: AlamedaLocationDetail7
data.value: L'objectif principal de Alameda est le centre de Fuente de la Placeta, construit à partir délicate pierre locale à l'époque du roi Carlos III, dans le Plaza de España. Jusqu'à ces dernières décennies, elle était encore la principale source d'eau douce pour la ville, et la largeur importante de la base de la fontaine, construite peut-être délibérément, il était impossible de combler un grand pichet sans se pencher et de tomber dans la fontaine. Villageois développé un truc de mettre le lanceur sur le terrain et de le remplir à l'aide d'un roseau de canne creuse. La proximité Plaza de la Constitution est une jolie place bordée d'arbres avec des bancs où les citadins prennent leur paseo du soir, marcher.

data.name: AlamedaLocationDetail8
data.value: Juste en dehors de la ville, le Mirador de la Camorra offre d'excellentes vues sur la ville et le paysage environnant, à environ 250 mètres plus haut que 430 mètres de l'Alameda d'altitude. Il ya un chemin facile vers le haut. A quelques kilomètres à l'ouest de la ville est la Laguna de la Ratosa, comme la proximité de Fuente de Piedra un endroit pour trouver des flamants roses et autres oiseaux migrateurs et une abondance de la faune.

data.name: AlamedaLocationDetail9
data.value: Principaux festivals de Alameda sont sa Février Candelaria procession, la fête de trois jours pour son saint patron, San Isidro Labrador, les 15-18 Mars et Août la feria, qui s'est tenue dans la première semaine du mois. La ville se spécialise toujours dans son travail avec l'alfa, le bois et la menuiserie, en particulier silleria, la production de sièges en bois.

data.name: AntequeraInfoDetail
data.value: Consultez notre guide de la ville d'Antequera zone pour plus d'informations:

data.name: ArchidonaLocationDetail1
data.value: Archidona se trouve au pied de la montagne Pico del Conjuro au milieu oliviers et de prairies, sur la route qui relie Alameda à la province de Grenade.

data.name: ArchidonaLocationDetail2
data.value: It boasts a myriad of places and elements of natural and urban interest. Grande and Chica Lagoons and La Hoz de Arroyo Martin are examples of the former, while the pick of the latter is the Octagonal Square, a construction built in the Mudejar style and inspired by French urbanism.

data.name: ArchidonaLocationDetail3
data.value: Other interesting monuments include Virgen de Gracia Sanctuary, built on the ruins of the old castle, the Nazarene Chapel and the old granary building.

data.name: ArchidonaLocationDetail4
data.value: Archidona dates back to prehistoric times, as proven by important archaeological findings pertaining to the Palaeolithic period. The first major settlers in the area were the túrdulos. The Phoenicians began the construction of the village walls.

data.name: ArchidonaLocationDetail5
data.value: The village was an important strategic location for the Carthaginians. They reinforced the walls and it was crucial in the war against the Romans. During the Roman era, it was known as Arx Domina, the Arabs modified this to Arxiduna, which is the origin of its present-day name.

data.name: ArchidonaLocationDetail6
data.value: The Moslem occupation consisted of several stages. Following the proclamation of Abderraman I as emir of Cordoba in 756, Archidona, a dependency of the aforementioned city, became the capital of the cora (region) of Rayya (an area which, roughly speaking, coincided with the modern-day province of Malaga). It was in the thick of the muladi (Christian convert to Islam) rebellion of the late 9th and early 10th centuries, led by Ben Hafsun, who turned it into a fortified town.

data.name: ArchidonaLocationDetail7
data.value: In 907, it was conquered again, this time by the emir Abd Allah. And, when Bobastro, a fortress at the centre of Omar Ben Hafsun's rebellion, fell into the hands of Abderraman III in 928, it was the start of a period of great prosperity for the region, in which commerce, industry and agriculture blossomed. However, this period of splendour ended with the political and economic division which accompanied the era known as the Taifa Kingdom period; by the end of the 11th century, the village's lands were abandoned and impoverished.

data.name: ArchidonaLocationDetail8
data.value: In 1238 it became a dependency of the Nazari Kingdom of Granada, and Archidona experienced its second boom, this time due largely to the silk trade. Before long, however, a new turn of events shattered the commercial links of the whole region: the 14th century saw the start of the Christian campaigns in the area, which became a border zone, its territory suffering frequent pillaging. It was finally captured in 1462 by Don Pedro de Giron, Grand Master of Calatrava.

data.name: ArchidonaLocationDetail9
data.value: Archidona's present-day location dates back to the 16th century, when construction began on the are known as Villa Baja. The village's long and eventful history, coupled with the desire of its inhabitants to preserve the artistic heritage born of the key role played by the village down the years, has resulted in Archidona being declared a Village of Historical and Artistic Importance.

data.name: CampillosLocationDetail
data.value: Cette petit ville paisible de la province de Málaga de moins que 8000 habitants, équidistante entre la Costa del Sol, Grenade et Séville, a été un important bovins élevage, de production de cuir et d'exploitation minière depuis l'époque romaine. Les fouilles archéologiques dans les environs ont découvert l'architecture romaine et des pièces de monnaie, ainsi que des laiton bustes d'Octavius, Claudius, Constantine et Trajan. De nos jours, cependant, il est principalement connu comme l'un des principaux arrêts sur la Algeciras-Grenade rail ligne.

data.name: CampillosLocationDetail1
data.value: Drivers, who will reach it 30km from Alameda on the N342 which continues on to Olvera, Arcos de la Frontera and Jerez de la Frontera, will also find it a worthwhile diversion to see the flocks of brilliant pink flamingos that, in season, nest in the nearby La Fuente de la Piedra ('fountain of stone') waterlands. Like much of Andalucía, its post-Roman history followed the familiar pattern of Visigothic and Arabic invasion. It fell to the Christian forces relatively early in the Reconquest, in 1324, when the town was almost totally destroyed. It was considered sufficiently important to both Arabs and Christians to have been the subject of several fierce battles, notably in 1237 between the army of Mohamed Alhamar, Moorish king of Granada, and rebels from Campillos and nearby Loja. After the fall of Granada in 1492, it was rebuilt and resettled by farmers and coal workers from Osuna and Teba.

data.name: CampillosLocationDetail2
data.value: The most important monument in Campillos is its central Iglesia Parroquial Nuestra Señora del Reposo, the parish church of our lady of rest, which is just off the town's plaza central. The impressive bell tower was built by Fray (father) Miguel de Santísimo Sacramento in the 16th century. Its chief architectural style is Doric, with two stone facades, one Doric, the other baroque. The main altar in the church features a pine tabernacle with eight columns 'jónicas', that is, of the Ionian or Ionic school of architecture, with the familiar fluted columns and elaborate capitals of classical Greek architecture.

data.name: CampillosLocationDetail3
data.value: Also worth seeing is the Ermita de San Benito, the town's patron saint. The saint's modest hermitage was built between 1578-1569 although the building seen today was extensively rebuilt in 1756 and 1814.

data.name: CampillosLocationDetail4
data.value: The vestiges of the town's Arab castle, el Castillo de Gobantes, loom over the centre.

data.name: CampillosLocationDetail5
data.value: The Fuente de las Piedras is in fact only one of more than half a dozen of lagoons in the surrounding countryside. Even at 540m above sea level, these are salt water lakes, one, the Laguna Salada, is a gigantic salt pan where salt has been harvested for hundreds of years.

data.name: CampillosLocationDetail6
data.value: The most important fiesta is the one celebrating patron saint San Benito Abad, which is held on July 10-11 every year. The town's summer feria happens every first fortnight of August.

data.name: CampillosLocationDetail7
data.value: The local speciality is Porra Campillera, a dryish soup or stew with tuna, eggs and ham, similar to another, better known, regional speciality, salmoreja, which uses oranges, fried fish, cod and tuna. Peasant specialities using garbanzos are also popular.

data.name: FuenteDetail
data.value: Dans le nord de la province de Malaga en Andalousie, 19 km d'Antequera est la Laguna de Fuente de Piedra, un célèbre lagon beau. Le plus grand lac naturel de la péninsule ibérique à 2,5 km de large et 6,5 km de long, il est un havre pour les oiseaux avec plus de 170 espèces différentes enregistrées ici.

data.name: FuenteDetail1
data.value: Apart from its abundant aquatic birds, it is well known for its flamingo population, the second largest colony of these birds in Europe after the French Camargue region and the only inland site on the continent where they breed. In spring flamingos flock here in their thousands to reproduce, attracted by the water's high salt content and the fact that it is shallow.

data.name: FuenteDetail2
data.value: Although in winter the lake fills up and covers around 15km2, it is seasonal, so it virtually dries out in summer. During times of scarcity, the flamingos may go as far as the Doñana National Park to find food.

data.name: FuenteDetail3
data.value: During Roman times, salt was extracted here and flamingos were hunted for their tongues, considered to be a delicacy. In the early 19th century people believed that the lake water had medicinal qualities, so the Laguna de Fuente de Piedra was not allowed to dry out completely, unlike other wetland areas in Spain.

data.name: FuenteDetail4
data.value: In the 1930s a salt company that owned the lake undertook a campaign to reduce the flamingo population, which was threatening their salt production.

data.name: FuenteDetail5
data.value: Luckily, the lake's ecological value was publicised and it became a magnet for birdwatchers and naturalists. In 1988 it was a declared a zone of special interest for birds (Zepa). The protected area covers 8,543ha.

data.name: FuenteDetail6
data.value: The best places to see the lake include the viewpoint by the visitors' centre, the Mirador de Cerro del Palo, and anywhere along the footpath Sendero de la Vicaría.

data.name: FuenteDetail7
data.value: There is a lakeside visitors' centre (952 111 715) at the Cerro del Palo, just off the Sierra de Yeguas road out of the Fuente de Piedra village. Here, there is plenty of information on the lake, much of it audiovisual. There are also guided tours available, for observing the birds and other wildlife, but these only run when the lake has water.

data.name: PalencianaDetail1
data.value: Town situated in the southern most part of the SubAndalusian, borders the province of Malaga 40 kms from this capital. Its name comes from Palencia because they were numerous people in the municipality removing oaks and making charcoal for the 13th century. Palenciana is noted for its architecture with the presence of whitewashed streets. The streets of old houses may be the traditional architecture of the earth, corresponding mainly to the nineteenth century. As for religious architecture you need to see the parish of San Miguel and the Hermitage of San Lucas.

data.name: priegoDetail1
data.value: Priego of Cordoba, called 'City of the water' for the multitude of springs that appear in its environment and 'Jewel of the Baroque Native of Cordoba' for the number of constructions of baroque style that it possesses. It is a locality of the province of Cordoba, judicial county capital in where there are 8 villages and 17 hamlets, all belonging to the region of the Union of Andalusia and is a member of the Route of the Caliphate.

data.name: priegoDetail2
data.value: Located in the south-east of the province of Cordoba, approximately 100 Kilometers from the capital, Priego de Cordoba is located in full heart of Andalucia, bordering on two provinces, in the eastern part Jaen and to the south-east Granada, and three administrative areas, to the Northwest of Baena, to the southwest of Rute and in the western part on Goat. It borders on the municipalities of Tójar, Alcaudete and Luque in the northern part, in the eastern part on those of Alcala la Real, Almedinilla and Montefrío, in the southern part on those of Algarinejo and Iznájar and in the western part on those of Rute, Carcabuey and Luque. Is An Administrative area's head-board that understands, in addition, the municipalities of Almedinilla, with a nature reserve of 31.568 Hectares with a high ecological interest for his vegetation, fauna and great landscape value of his environment.

data.name: priegoDetail3
data.value: In the south-east limit Horconera is located, with the highest peak of the whole province. The Mangy one with 1570 meters or the Vermilion peak with 1.476 meters. It presents a flat area in direction towards the North and mountainous in other parts being cut by some small valleys. In the southern part there are situated diverse hamlets that take the names of 'Priego's Saw', 'Saw of the Mangy one' and 'Rute's Saw'. Also one finds in big cercanías heights, as Albayate's nearby Saw, with heights near 1.300 meters and that has been declared as complex of Tourist Interest

data.name: PuentegenilDetail1
data.value: Puente Genil est une grande ville dans la province Spanish de Córdoba, située à environ 45 miles (70 km) de la ville de Córdoba. Il a une population de 30.033 (13.922 hommes, 14.217 femmes).

data.name: PuentegenilDetail2
data.value: The name comes from the bridge over the river Genil. The town is an agricultural centre, also known for its Semana Santa-celebration, contracted in the local vernacular to "mananta". The important unifying element is the bridge, built in a place that was coming fordable used since ancient symbol of union between two shores that were once distinct provinces: the right bank in Cordoba, known as Don Gonzalo pontoon under the Marquis of Priego, the left in Sevilla, Miragenil, belonging to the Marquis of Estepa. It had to be a Queen, the Regent Maria Cristina, mother of Elizabeth II, who arrange for the union of the two banks by Royal Decree in 1834, after several failed attempts to agree.

data.name: PuentegenilDetail3
data.value: Puente Genil has interesting architecture, especially, religious, most of them built during the seventeenth and eighteenth centuries. But perhaps the most significant for its symbolism, is the bridge over the river Genil. Its first building as stone bridge dating from 1561. What Hernán Ruiz II built to replace the old wooden pier. The two twin arches were a later work, conducted in 1703. And the original brick arch was blown up by the French architect Leopoldo Lemonier in 1874.

data.name: RuteDetail
data.value: Situé au sud de la province de Cordoue, sur la frontière avec la province de Malaga et arrosé par les rivières Genil, La Hoz et Anzur, se trouve le village de Rute. Une ville agricole avec une vocation industrielle et aujourd'hui elle est célèbre pour le chocolat et Aniz.

data.name: RuteDetail1
data.value: Located 90 km from Cordoba city, Jaen and Malaga, Its main source of economy is the agriculture, the farming of olive trees. It is a large town referred to by locals as a mountain village with the feature of having one of the biggest reservoirs in the region. The weather is typically Mediterranean although hotter in summer and colder in winter, with rainy springs and short autumns.

data.name: RuteDetail2
data.value: Rute has historicals links since the Neolitic period, La Cueva Negra. There are the remains of a castle from the Muslim period in a village of Roman origins, Cisimbrum, Zambra; El Canuto, is a watch tower from the Muslim period and Rute Viejo an old city from mid thirteenth century. Apart from all the churches, the Town Hall has old houses since 16th century.

data.name: RuteDetail3
data.value: The history of Rute has been outstanding because of its position in the boundaries of two different regions. In the Middle Ages, the region of Granada and the region of Cordoba, very frequently changed governors in short time periods.

data.name: AlboloteDetail
data.value: Albolote est entouré de magnifiques paysages. Sierra Elvira offre aux visiteurs de nombreuses occasions d'expérimenter le contact avec la nature dans un domaine profondément humanisé.

data.name: AlboloteDetail1
data.value: A historical monument to visit is Church of Our Lady of the Incarnation within the village. The Mudejar style church dates from the sixteenth century and was designed by the architect Ambrosio de Vico. You have to admire the altar and the coffered ceilings by Pablo Rojas, Gibiria Barnabas and Martin de Aranda. Another monument of the town is The Watchtower .

data.name: AlboloteDetail2
data.value: It is at the eastern end of the Sierra Elvira stone mass of the silhouette of The Tower rises recently illuminated, highlighting the simplicity and beauty of it. Built in the thirteenth century as a watchtower of the Moorish era, their function was called surveillance corridor Cubillas, gateway to the North of Granada, as well as monitoring the Vega del Genil and was part of the defensive system and communications network during the Arab Muslim rule created throughout our country.

data.name: AlboloteDetail3
data.value: From the original building only one tower remains circular plant is located on a hill near the town from which the entire Vega and Cubillas row dominates and enhances the Sierra itself as a natural balcony and separator Vega and Cubillas depression.

data.name: AlboloteDetail4
data.value: Albolote has a Children's Park ("Albolut") and pioneered a road project Andalusia as educational training. It is further characterized by being made a dozen replicas of iconic buildings of the town buildings, including City Hall, the Church and the Market. An enclosure that no longer can be viewed.

data.name: AlboloteDetail5
data.value: Recently, Albolote has become part of the "Route of the Nazari", tourist and cultural project of the Andalusian Legacy. This means greater potential for tourism in the municipality.

data.name: AlcaudeteDetail
data.value: Alcuacete est une municipalité du sud de Spain. Il y a plus de 200 sites archéologiques à Alcaucete, dépouilles d'une intense et continue humaine occupation depuis le Paléolithique temps.

data.name: AlcaudeteDetail1
data.value: It is home to a 12th-14th Moorish castle, located on the top of the hill commanding the town. Other sights include the Santa Maria la Mayor (15th century). Here is a large English community living in the town and surrounding villages. Plenty of bars and restaurants. Real Spanish living.

data.name: AlcaudeteDetail2
data.value: The old Al-Andalus castle of Alcaudete is a proud and imposing construction, located in what was a strategic enclave between Christians and Muslims, set between the mountains and olive fields of Alcaucete. The castle was ceded by the Castilian Monarchs to the Military Order of Calatrava. The soldiers are who built most of the castle (13th-14th century) that is preserved in a extraordinary way. It is constructed on a hill overlooking the town of Alcaudete, and consists of a walled polygonal area that adapts to the slopes of the hill. The castle consist in seven towers: two can be found on the main gate, a rounded arch enclosed in a rectangular Moorish moulding (alfiz). Inside the walls there is a high and imposing keep, which in the 16th century was adapted as a stately residence by the recently named Counts of Alcaudete, the residents of the town.

data.name: AlcaudeteDetail3
data.value: Within the municipality of Alcaudete there are two protected natural areas: the nature reserve lagoon of Chince and lagoon Honda.

data.name: AlcaudeteDetail4
data.value: The most characteristic wildlife of Alcaudete are the common badger, (Sierra orbs Ahillos, Chaparral, etc..), the hedgehog which is also common in all areas of Alcaudete and is especially seen in Los Noguerones, the bobcats which in phase of extinction, they calculate that there are living between 3 and 7 couples, mostly in the Sierra Ahillos and some in the Sierra Orbs.

data.name: CestilloDetail
data.value: Castillo de Locubín est un village situé dans le coin sud-ouest de la province de Jaen, en Andalousie, en Spain. Selon le recensement de 2006, le village a une population de 5000 habitants.

data.name: CestilloDetail1
data.value: Castillo de Locubín is a pueblo blanco or white village, so named for the white-washed external walls of the houses. It is located in the foothills of the Sierra Sur. The Moorish castle is in ruins. The 16th century church is dedicated to St Peter the Apostle. Castillo main local crafts are pottery and ceramics. During the first week in June, a cherry fair to celebrate the Cherry harvest is held, with competitions for the best liqueurs, desserts and cuisine based on cherry. Castillo is 7 kilometers north of Alcalá la Real and 2km from the N432 main road.

data.name: guidealcalaDetail1
data.value: This delightful large town has a population of approximately 22,000 and is located on the N432 between Cordoba (85km) and Granada (47km) although, technically, it falls within the province of Jaen. The town has a large English community and there are several English bars and a language college. The town has an impressive fortress and was a strategic stronghold during medieval times, and subsequently occupied by the Moors in 713. Thereafter, Alcala la Real was the scene of frequent battles between the Moors and the Christians. This tumultuous period lasted until 1341 when Alfonso XI gained control of the town. The crown established an abbey here which was deemed the headquarters from where to launch a major offensive on Granada.

data.name: guidealcalaDetail2
data.value: February 2 La Candeleria. A mini 'fallas' (Valencia) when bonfires are lit throughout the town. Holy Week An important religious holiday with daily processions taking place through the main streets of the town.

data.name: guidealcalaDetail3
data.value: May 15 - San Isidro Locals enjoy a picnic in the surrounding countryside.

data.name: guidealcalaDetail4
data.value: June 24 - San Juan Bonfires and fireworks

data.name: guidealcalaDetail5
data.value: August 15 - Virgin de la Mercedes A dazzling procession with more than 12,000 lit candles. September 21-25 Annual fair of San Mateo

data.name: HumilladroLocationDetail
data.value: La région municipale de Humilladero occupe une étroite bande de territoire entre les communes de Fuente de Piedra et Mollina, au nord de la région d'Antequera. La région s'étend de la limite des provinces de Malaga et de Séville à la chaîne de montagnes du même nom, au pied de laquelle vous trouverez la ville. Le paysage est une plaine ondulante doucement couvert d'oliviers et de céréales.

data.name: HumilladroLocationDetail1
data.value: Au sud de la chaîne de montagne de Humilladero (650 ms.) Rompt la monotonie avec un relief plus prononcé et une masse abondante de pinèdes. Bien que la fondation de la ville remonte au 15ème siècle - une époque antérieure à la conquête d'Antequera par les troupes chrétiennes, les premiers documents fiables datent ses origines à l'année 1618, la date qui apparaît dans une inscription dans les fondations à l' base de la Cruz de la Humilladero à l'entrée de la localité.

data.name: HumilladroLocationDetail2
data.value: Les premiers habitants de Humilladero occupé une série de maisons qui entourent le couvent du 15ème siècle. Le nom lui-même est réputé pour être à l'occasion quand Infante D. Fernando a prêté serment sur l'épée de San Fernando qui il avait effectué depuis la côte vers les troupes de Séville avec qui il manquait à s'unir pour conquérir Antequera.Humilladero Andalucia feria D. Fernando et ses troupes tous agenouillés et ont juré de ne pas prendre possession de l'épée jusqu'à Antequera a été conquise.

data.name: martosdetail1
data.value: La ville de Martos (Oui c'est assez gros pour être appelé une ville) est située dans la province de Jaén dans la communauté autonome d'Andalousie dans le centre-sud de l'Espagne.

data.name: martosdetail2
data.value: Il a une population de 24063 habitants, ce qui Martos la cinquième plus grande municipalité de la province. La ville est située sur une crête occidentale de la chaîne de montagnes Sierra Jabalcuz. Il appartient à la région métropolitaine de Jaén, dont il est considéré comme la deuxième ville la plus importante après la capitale. Propriétés à vendre ont toujours été moins cher que de dire Alcaudete, si vous ne pouvez vraiment obtenir une bonne affaire en ce moment.

data.name: martosdetail3
data.value: Il ya une grande communauté de langue anglaise et de nombreuses occasions de se faire des amis nouveaux et durables.

data.name: martosdetail4
data.value: Son économie est basée sur l'agriculture, notamment la culture de l'olivier. Martos est considéré comme le premier producteur d'huile d'olive du monde. Il est important aussi de diverses industries, notamment celles liées au traitement de plastique. La ville a été liée à la colonie romaine de Colonia Augusta Gemella, et à partir de la 8e siècle a été dominé par les Maures en vertu de divers Etats islamiques pour plus de 500 ans. En 1225, le roi Ferdinand III de Castille et Leon a capturé la ville des Maures et l'a incorporé dans son royaume.

data.name: martosdetail5
data.value: Pendant le Moyen Age, Martos est devenu un lieu stratégique, et ses défenses ont été renforcées avec la construction de nombreuses fortifications dans la ville.

data.name: martosdetail6
data.value: A la fin du 19e siècle et au début du 20e siècle, Martos subi développement économique et urbain significatif (reflété dans l'architecture de la ville), en grande partie en raison de la richesse provenant de la production industrielle d'huile d'olive. Martos est ainsi devenu l'une des villes les plus prospères de l'est de l'Andalousie.

data.name: MollinaLocationDetail
data.value: Il a été une colonie humaine sur le site de cette petite ville (population actuelle un peu plus de 4.800) depuis le néolithique. Juste à 15km au nord-ouest de Antequera sur l'A92, sur les pentes inférieures de la Sierra de Mollina, cette option est réglée en parfaite olive et du pays en céréales. Il est également à quelques dix kilomètres du lac Laguna de Fuente de la Piedra, célèbre pour ses flamants roses.

data.name: MollinaLocationDetail1
data.value: Le nom provient en fait d'une tour de fraisage, la Torre Mollina (similaire aux Torremolinos, sur la Costa), qui a disparu peu de temps au Moyen Âge. Une autre théorie affirme que le nom provient de ses dirigeants romains et dérive du latin "mollis ', suave, ou fade.

data.name: MollinaLocationDetail2
data.value: Il reste peu de soit néolithique ou romaine Mollina, au-delà des artefacts néolithiques trouvés dans le voisinage de la Sierra de la Camorra, et de sept km de Mollina lui-même, le mausolée romain rectangulaire en forme de La Capuchina.

data.name: MollinaLocationDetail3
data.value: Quatre km en dehors de la ville se trouvent les ruines du fort de Castellum de Santillán, l'origine une colonie construite autour d'une villa romaine et dépendances entourant couvrant une superficie de 1400 mètres carrés. Le Castellum a été renforcé avec des murs défensifs, un signe des bouleversements dans cette partie de l'Andalousie à l'époque romaine.

data.name: MollinaLocationDetail4
data.value: La ville actuelle, cependant, remonte surtout à une époque plus paisible, au 16ème siècle, lorsque la reconquête a été gagné et les terres morcelé de l'agriculture pour les vainqueurs. Ainsi, le temps de paix Mollina a grandi autour d'un couvent, le couvent de la Ascension, plutôt que d'un campement fortifié comme de nombreuses villes andalouses. (Ne manquez pas le cadran beau sur le covent façade.) À son apogée, l'agriculture, les oliveraies de Mollina étaient si productive que l'église paroissiale de San Cayetano, construit en 1687, a été modifié pour Nuestra Señora de la Oliva.

data.name: MollinaLocationDetail5
data.value: Mollina obtenu son indépendance de proximité Antequera au début du 19ème siècle, bien qu'à cette époque de l'agriculture en Andalousie était en déclin. Depuis les années 1960, la population a diminué, comme le jeune chef à la côte pour travailler. Pourtant Mollina produit encore un étonnant 80 pour cent du vin produit dans la province de Málaga.

data.name: MollinaLocationDetail6
data.value: L'hôtel principal (il n'y a que deux), l'hôtel Molino del Saydo, à quelques kilomètres au sud, est un exemple d'un hôtel typique espagnol bord de la route qui a souffert de la perte de la circulation de transit, suite à la construction de l'autoroute A92 Séville-Grenade au début des années 1990.

data.name: MollinaLocationDetail7
data.value: Mollina a quatre grandes fêtes annuelles. La Candelaria, ou chandelles procession, est célébrée le premier jour de Février, et, en mai il ya un Romería, ou procession dans le pays, en l'honneur de la Virgen de la Oliva. La feria d'été de la ville est précoce, dans la deuxième semaine d'Août, mais c'est peut-être pour faire place à peut-être le plus important festival, le festival des vendanges, ou Feria de la Vendimia, dans la deuxième semaine de Septembre.

data.name: SirraDeYeguasDetail
data.value: Un village à la frontière entre les provinces de Séville et Malaga dont le paysage s'étend des plaines de la région d'Antequera à la campagne de Séville, séparé par les montagnes de la Sierra de los Caballos.

data.name: SirraDeYeguasDetail1
data.value: Its most notable monument is the Immaculate Conception Church; also to be found here are archaeological remains from the Roman period such as Peñuela and La Herriza villas and the baths at La Haza de Estepa.

data.name: SirraDeYeguasDetail2
data.value: Though founded in the 16th century, Neolithic remains found on the outskirts of the village bear witness to the presence of primitive man in the area. Further sites, a necropolis, hot baths and other archaeological relics have been discovered pertaining to the Roman era.

data.name: SirraDeYeguasDetail3
data.value: In 1549, the Sierra de Yeguas was under the jurisdiction of Estepa and belonged to the estate of the Marquis of this village, as indicated by the coat of arms to be found in the parish church.

data.name: SirraDeYeguasDetail4
data.value: Until 1874, religious affairs in the village were controlled by the "verenullius" curacy, which made it dependent on Papal jurisdiction. In civil matters, it belonged to the province of Seville until the 17th century.

data.name: VillanuevadeDetail
data.value: Situé dans le nord-est de la région d'Antequera, dans un paysage essentiellement constitué de collines et de crêtes qui abritent des oliviers et de champs de céréales. Elle remonte au 18ème siècle, lorsque les bâtiments qui ont commencé à apparaître autour du monastère franciscain finissent par former un village. Villanueva de Algaidas fut le berceau de la célèbre sculpteur Ortiz de Berrocal, dont les œuvres sont logés dans un musée intéressant dans le village.

data.name: VillanuevadeDetail1
data.value: D'intérêt sont Alcaides nécropole Los, les grottes de la Sierra de Arcas et El Pedroso.

data.name: VillanuevadeDetail2
data.value: Quatre villages dans la province de Malaga sont appelés "Villanueva": Villanueva de Algaidas, Villanueva de Tapia, Villanueva del Rosario et Villanueva del Trabuco. Tous les quatre sont situées dans le nord-est de la province, les deux premiers, plus au nord, entre les limites municipales de Cuevas de San Marcos et Archidona et près de la frontière avec la province de Grenade, à l'est; Villanueva del Rosario et Villanueva del Trabuco se trouvent dans le nord de la région Axarquia et sont également adjacent à Archidona et la province de Grenade.

data.name: VillanuevadeDetail3
data.value: Ces quatre villages ont tous été fondés presque en même temps au 18ème siècle sur les ordres de Charles III dans le cadre d'un plan visant à repeupler les régions de l'Andalousie qui étaient pratiquement inhabitées et qui, par conséquent, souvent servi de refuges et de repaires sûrs de bandits de grand chemin.

data.name: VillanuevadeDetail4
data.value: Toutefois, la commune de Villanueva de Algaidas remonte à l'époque beaucoup plus tôt, comme en témoignent les vestiges préhistoriques à Los Alcaides nécropole.

data.name: VillanuevadeDetail5
data.value: Le terme "Algaida" semble suggérer une présence arabe et est probablement dérivé des "al-gaida", ce qui signifie "forêt dense".

data.name: VillanuevadeDetail6
data.value: Le village que nous connaissons aujourd'hui est apparu à la suite de la fondation d'un monastère franciscain à côté de Burriana Stream, maintenant presque entièrement détruite. Le règlement original était connu comme La Atalaya. Peu à peu, un certain nombre de colonies agricoles ont commencé à apparaître, comme La Rincona et Zamarra-qui a finalement combinés pour former un village sous le nom de Villanueva de Algaidas.

data.name: aboutinlandandaluciaDetai1
data.value:
Avec des bureaux à Málaga (Mollina) et Jaén (Alcalá la Real), nous pouvons vous aider à chaque étape.

Notre équipe est dédié à vous trouver la meilleure valeur. Vous pouvez choisir parmi notre portefeuille de propriétés, constamment actualisées, ou contactez-nous.

Au cours des trois derniers mois 80% de nos ventes étaient pour les maisons coûtant moins de 100 000€, 15% ont été moins de 150 000€ et 5% ont été des propriétés plus chères, mais avec de grandes remises.

data.name: aboutinlandandaluciaDetai2
data.value: Soins personnels et d'attention à vous

data.name: aboutinlandandaluciaDetai3
data.value: Notre attention personnelle ne faiblira pas après que vous avez trouvé la propriété de vos rêves. Nous sommes également heureux et prêt à aider et donner des conseils sur tous les aspects de votre achat.

data.name: aboutinlandandaluciaDetai4
data.value: Nous pouvons vous aider avec les changements du compte l'électricité et de l'eau, l’ouverture de comptes bancaires, l'application NIE etc.

data.name: aboutinlandandaluciaDetai5
data.value: Vous pouvez compter sur notre expérience et expertise à être le guide pour vous aider à acheter votre nouvelle propriété en Andalousie.

data.name: aboutinlandandaluciaDetai6
data.value: Nous sommes fiers de notre service personnalisé, essayant de vous donner autant d'aide que possible. Comme nous voulons que vous recevez l'attention individuelle dont vous avez besoin, essayez de réserver un rendez-vous avant de quitter votre maison. De cette façon nous pouvons être prêts et disponibles pour vous personnellement à l’heure et la date qui vous convient.

data.name: aboutinlandandaluciaDetai7
data.value: Below is a list of our inland properties in Andalucia sorted by province and in alphabetical order:

data.name: JaujaLocationDetail1
data.value: Jauja tire son nom de l'arabe, qui vient de "Xauxa" qui signifie passage ou porte, comme son emplacement était le point utilisé par les Arabes pour se connecter avec les plaines de Grenade Ecija.

data.name: JaujaLocationDetail2
data.value: Jauja is located to the Southwest of the province of Cordoba, in the municipality of Lucena at a distance of 25 Km The village is between 220 and 240 meters above sea level on the banks of the River Genil, with coordinates of 37 ° 18 '10' north latitude and 4 ° 39' 22' west longitude.

data.name: JaujaLocationDetail3
data.value: Its terrain is broken, placing the core in the foot of a mountain of mountains, and its quite hilly relief, because apart of being in the foothills of the Subbéticas. The nature of its soil has made riverbeds that have been embedded, forming numerous slopes on its banks and many streams. The soil of this land is made up of Quaternary sedimentary layers, strongly affected by erosion. These lands are divided into red and Blancares.

data.name: JaujaLocationDetail4
data.value: As for hydrography, the area is housed between the beds of the rivers Genil and Anzur, with a drainage network formed by numerous streams, among which are those of San Miguel, Bermejo, White, "Colorao" Fuillerat et Monk. These are dry most of the year, but in the rainy fall with great flow, causing erosion of arable land, and sometimes floods.

data.name: JaujaLocationDetail5
data.value: Jauja still maintains its configuration as a people with elements of the architecture that place immediately in your environment and rural countryside. In regard to the architecture of the houses you can still find small houses with lime and tile as defining elements.

data.name: JaujaLocationDetail6
data.value: The two main local festivals are held in honor of their patron: St. Dominic and the Virgin of the Rosary, the first on August 4 and the second on October 7, during which the image in procession of the Employer.

data.name: JaujaLocationDetail7
data.value: Today it has a population of approximately 1,000 inhabitants of most its main activity is agriculture and livestock. Notably, the main activity of olive cultivation and the three banks of orchards there on the banks of the Genil, which in recent years has had a boom in greenhouse cultivation.

data.name: JaujaLocationDetail8
data.value: The streets that make up this town are: Church Street, Mill Street and the street Lawsuit that form the backbone of the town and are parallel to each other and other cross like Ronda, waiters or lane bridge Neighborhood and Alley.

data.name: BenamejiDetail
data.value: La ville a une population de 5072 habitants selon le recensement de 2006.

data.name: BenamejiDetail1
data.value: La meilleure vue de la ville est de la colline voisine où se dresse le sanctuaire de Notre-Dame de Grâce

data.name: BenamejiDetail2
data.value: Walking through the village, the most important monument is the parish church which is dedicated to the Immaculate Conception. Its facade of yellow blocks, which faces the square and the single arch opens onto a niche of a stony image of the Immaculate Conception. In the epistle side of the tower stands the eighteenth century square brick, except for the belfry, which is octagonal.

data.name: BenamejiDetail3
data.value: The Constitution Square is a reflection of everyday life. Encouraged, where women go to buy, contemplate about dynamic trade, etc.

data.name: BenamejiDetail4
data.value: Benameji currently known for its urban design, which comes from the mid sixteenth century, parallel and perpendicular streets, characteristic of both Renaissance urban populations as new creation. This monument stands the Main Plaza, a large square space that once was chaired by the palace of the Marquis of Benameji. Where after simple facade hid a grandiose Renaissance courtyard with arches or columns of jasper discount on colorado, several rooms with coffered ceilings and a staircase in which there was a coffered dome style Hernán Ruiz. The site of the palace is occupied by the Town Hall to retain shields in front of the palace.

data.name: BenamejiDetail5
data.value: The architect was also responsible for the magnificent stonework bridge over the river Genil, whose channel anchuroso saves a bow and two smaller ponds separated by semi-cylindrical.

data.name: BenamejiDetail6
data.value: At the end of Benameji Castle is located Gomez Arias, of Muslim origin, now only some remains, mainly the walls of a tower.

data.name: carmonaCarmona
data.value: Carmona is a fascinating town and well worth a visit, whether you are a history buff or not. From Carmona is a 28km-long greenway to Alcalá de Guadaíra, the Vía Verde of the Hills, which you can go on foot, bike or horseback.

data.name: carmonaclose
data.value: Close by to the east is Santa Maria, a stately Gothic church built over the former main mosque, whose elegant patio is retained. Like many of Carmona's churches, it is topped by an evocative Mudejar tower and part of the original minaret may still be spotted. Dominating the ridge of the town are the massive ruins of Pedro's palace, destroyed by an earthquake in 1504 and now taken over by a gracious if expensive parador.

data.name: carmonaEnclosed
data.value: Enclosed in subterranean chambers hewn from the rock, the tombs are often frescoed and contain a series of niches in which many of the funeral urns remain intact. Some of the larger tombs have vestibules with stone benches for funeral banquets and several retain carved family emblems. Opposite is a partly excavated ampitheatre

data.name: carmonatotheleft
data.value: To the left the town comes to an abrupt halt at the Roman Puerta de Córdoba from where the original Cordoba road drops down to a vast plain.

data.name: castil
data.value: Castil de Campos is located 10 km northeast of Priego de Cordoba and 2 km south of Source Tojar, totally immersed in the region of Cordoba. Local to and bordered by the municipalities of Priego, Source Tojar, Alcaudete, Alcala la Real and Almedinilla.

data.name: enterance
data.value: At the entrance to the town is the Puerto de Sevilla a grand if ruinous fortified gateway which leads to the historic old part of the city. Within the wall, narrow streets meander past Mudejar churches and Renaissance mansions.Up still further is the Plaza San Fernando which is comparatively small but dominated by splendid Moorish style buildings, behind here is a bustling fruit and vegetable market which, like all markets in Andalucia,appropriately reflects what is in season at any given time.

data.name: smalltown
data.value: This small town, located in an area of gentle hills and surrounded by olive groves, it opens on the north and northeast, the plain, one of the most fertile valleys in the area, which ends in the river or stream Caicena. It sits on the northern slope of the Rowan Tower, about 700 meters from where on clear days you can see a splendid and extensive view. At this Almedinilla road gives way to higher mountains in the provinces of Jaen and Granada.

data.value: This small town, located in an area of gentle hills and surrounded by olive groves, it opens on the north and northeast, the plain, one of the most fertile valleys in the area, which ends in the river or stream Caicena. It sits on the northern slope of the Rowan Tower, about 700 meters from where on clear days you can see a splendid and extensive view. At this Almedinilla road gives way to higher mountains in the provinces of Jaen and Granada.

data.name: carmonatotheroman
data.value: The Roman necropolis is particular noteworthy. It lies on a low hill at the opposite end of Carmona amid cypress trees and contains more than nine hundred family tombs dating from the second century BC to the fourth century AD.

data.name: Located
data.value: Located on a low hill overlooking a fertile plain, Carmona is a picturesque, small town with a magnificent 15th century tower built in imitation of Seville's Giralda. This is the first thing you see and sets an appropriate tone for the place. Not surprisingly, given its proximity, Carmona shares a similar history to Seville, and was an important Roman city which, under the Moors was often governed by a brother of the Sevillan ruler. Later Pedro the Cruel built a palace within its castle which he used as his royal residence in the country

data.name: descblog
data.value:
As well as many other dishes from various parts of the world, paella evolved from  local produce. It is estimated that its preparation began between the fifteenth and sixteenth centuries, when the inhabitants of some of the rural areas of Valencia started to mix the different ingredients they had available to make a fast and easy meal for the farmers and shepherds.

In principle, they added fresh vegetables to rice with chicken and rabbit, as well as saffron and olive oil, ingredients that gave it its characteristic flavour of the Mediterranean. As paella became more popular, seafood and shellfish were added.

There are many stories that revolve around this mythical Spanish recipe, one of them tells that it is a dish that was usually consumed in the evenings. Another legend, dating to the Spanish War of Independence, relates that a French general, impressed by the exquisite taste of paella, told a woman that "for each new plate of rice cooked he would free a Spanish prisoner." In the end, the military had to release 176 prisoners.

The exact origin of paella, pride of any Valencian, is located in the rice area near the lake of Albufera.  Olive oil and saffron, essential ingredients for its preparation were added to the original recipe. Similarly, the farmers of the time, in addition to the meat and vegetables they had on hand, incorporated tavella and ferraura (two native types of green beans) and garrofó (a flat and white bean), as well as paprika, rosemary and snails.


Why is it called paella?

 

This dish, one of the most famous in Spain, owes its name to the frying pan in which it is cooked called a "paella" or "paellera". The shape of this pan should be a minimum diameter of 30 centimeters, with edges of 7 to 12 centimeters, not very deep, with two handles fixed to the sides that support the stew and allow it to be transported easily.

For an authentic Valencian paella, the Ministry of Agriculture of the Valencian Government has decreed that ten ingredients must be included,  chicken, rabbit, basil (green bean), garrofon, tomato, rice, olive oil, water, saffron and salt.  However, garlic, artichoke, duck, paprika, snails or rosemary can also be added.

Over time, other variations have been created of which "paella marinera" is the most popular and accepted. In this one vegetables and meat are replaced by diverse seafood, molluscs and fish. (In addition to supplying the water for fish stock - not sure about this bit!). 

Another type of paella is "mixed" in which, as it's name suggests  meat, chicken or rabbit is mixed with seafood. This recipe is rarely consumed in Valencia but will be found in most non-Valencian or foreign restaurants.

 Paella alicantina"  is made from a broth, which contains fish (sepia, prawns and swordfish) and meat (chicken or rabbit). Its elaboration originates from the south of Valencia, especially in the counties of l'Alacantí-Alcoià or the Foia of Castalla.

Paella became famous first in Spain, and began to spread to other cultures and countries such as Belgium and France after the nineteenth century.  Its rise in most continents was mainly due to being a festive dish that became common in family gatherings, and was born to gather people together and to celebrate.
